coredata.dc:title: Orientation and bonding of ethylene and ethylidyne on Pt(111) by means of near-edge x-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy
coredata.dc:creator: Koestner, R.J.
Stöhr, J.
Gland, J.L.
Horsley, J.A.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) spectra have been measured for ethylene chemisorbed on Pt(111) at 90 and 300 K. From the polarization dependence of the spectra at 90 K, ethylene is found to lie down with a π bond to the surface. The spectra collected at 300 K indicate a CC bond normal to the surface in ethylidyne, and a SCF Xα calculation was carried out to assign the K-edge transitions in this species. The ethylidyne carboncarbon bond (which is nominally a single bond) appears to be shorter (≈0.03 A) than that for chemisorbed ethylene.

The spccira have been taken neai the K-cdf.cs (within 30 eV) of carbon, nitrogen or oxygen, and aie dominal- cd by transitions lioin the Is lu bound ui quaa- hound molecular levels. In (his study, we have collect- ed NFXAFS spectra forcthylcne adsoibed on P (l 11) at 90 and 300 K and used SCI-' Xa scatteicd wave cal- culations to help assiftn the measured transilions. Our data indicates that cthylene lies down on Pt(l 11) in a n-Aondcd configuration at 90 K and that the C C bond lotalcs to become perpendicular to the surface with cthylidync (-(' 013) formation at 300 K The experiments were carried out at the Stanford Synchrotron Kadiation Laboutoiy on bcani line I with the use of the grasshopper monochiomatoi (1200 lincs/mm) (4|. The absorption cross section in the caibon K-cdge legion (275 <. fiw < 310 cV) was measured by monitoring the secondary electron yield from the sample with a channclplatc detector mount- ed close to the sample's axis of rotation. The double- 332 grid rclaidirit' delecloi Dpci.ilcd with the first {;nd at ground and the second at 200 V to cliriiinatc low- cncrRy secondary electrons and thereby enhance the surface sensitivity. The ancle of incidence of the plane.polariy.cd X-ray beam was varied between near- grazing at 20 (with the electric field vecloi A' neaily pcrpendiculai lu the surlacc) and 90 (with A" parallel to the surface). Al-.S (with a double-pass CMA) .md F-I were used to check for impurities and defects on the Pi surface, while 0^ treatments arid/or Ar'*' sputtering were employed to dean the surface (of mostly carbon). The base pressure during these ex- periments was maintained below 10"I0 Torr. Our normali/cd NEXAF.S spectra shown m rip,. 1 for ethylcnc adsorbed on Pt(l 11) at "O K support a n-bondcd rather than a di-o-bondcd species. Tlic di-o- bondcd species was favored by high-resolution elec- tion energy loss spectroscopy (HREEI.S) (5,61 where the vibrational frequencies for cthylene adsorbed on Pl( 111 ) at 90 K weie closer to a di-o-bonded analogue ( 1,2-dibromoethane) than to a ff-bonded analogue (Zcisc's salt). At near-grazing incidence, an intense bound state transition (peak A) is observed at 0 9-2614/84/S 03 00 Elsevier Science Publishcis B.V (North-Holland 1'hysics Publishuip, Division) Volume 105. number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 March 1984 Fig- 1-NEXAFS spectra of ethylene chernisorbed on Pt(lll) at 90 K obtained for incidence angles of 20 and 90 - The measured XPS binding energy which corresponds to the ab- sorption threshold is also shown- 284-8 eV, slightly above the C Is excitation threshold or XPS binding energy (283.4 eV) [7]- This can be as- signed to either a IS-*OQ^ orbital in di-o-bonded ethylene where the ffQ>( orbital is an antibonding combination of a carbon sp3 and a platinum d orbital or a Is ->- IT* orbital excitation in ir-bonded ethylene. Peak A is completely absent at normal incidence where we instead observe a broader peak B at 293.0 eV that can be assigned to the Is -> a^c (quasi-bound state or o-shape resonance) excitation- From this polarization dependence, we immediately see that the carbon carbon bond is parallel or nearly parallel to the surface [1,2]- That is, the Is ->- o^c transition has a large intensity when E is oriented parallel to the sur- face and has a much smaller intensity when E is ro- tated 20 from the surface nonnal- UsLng the polarization dependence, we can now as- sign the bound state transition. The di-o-bonding model can be ruled out since it predicts that a size- able bound state transition (peak A) intensity remains at normal incidence which we do not find experimen- tally. To show this, we take the caibon covalent radius ofethyhdyne as determined by LEED (0.61-0.69 A) [8,9], a carbon carbon single bond distance of 150 A, and the Pt lattice spacing of 2.77 A and calculate a o-bond angle to the surface normal of^ O0 - This im- plies a reduction m the intensity of peak A by only a factor of 4 as we move from grazing to normal inci- dence [1]. In the TT-bonding model, the antibonding (ir* d) orbital is filled during the K-edge transition- This or- bital is mostly it* in character and also has a vanishing dipole matrix element parallel to the surface so the l s -> (ir* d) transition probability should be exactly zero at normal incidence, as measured- Fig- 2 shows NEXAFS spectra taken of the ethy- lene overlayer at 300 K. An ethylidyne (= N3) species was found to form at this temperature by HREELS, TDS, UPS, dynamical LEED [5,10], and later by angular resolved UPS [11]- We see bound state transitions (peaks A) at 285-4 and 285.7 eV at 0=90 and 0=20 , respectively. A quasi-bound state excitation (peak B) is observed at 2953 eV (11.0 eV above threshold. 2843 eV [7]) at an incidence angle of 20 but not at an incidence angle of 90 . The latter can easily be assigned to a Is -> o^ - transition which 280 290 300 310 PHOTON ENERGY (eV) Fig. 2. PHYSICS I.KITKRS 16 March 1984 is consistent with a vertical C C axis as determined by dynamical U:!:!) [81.11 REH I .S |10l. and ARUPS 111 ]. The assignment of the bound slate transitions, however, is less obvious and M a SCr- Xcr calculation [121 was carried out on a CIliCPl-i cluster to dctci- minc the nature of the unoccupied oibitals. The nuclear positions used in ths cluster calcula- tion wcic taken from previous LLED results |8,9|. The cluster model consisted of the clhylidync species placed symmetrically above a triangle of three Pt ?toms with the C -C axis perpendicular to l his triangle. The o values used for hydrogen, carbon, platinum and the outer sphere were 0.77725,0.75928. 07 and 0.72 respectively. The calculation was carried oui using touching muffin tin spheres. The calculated molecular orbital energy levels tor the C^CPt^ clus- ter arc shown in rig. 3. The highest occupied orbital is doubly degenerate and lies ==1 cV above the "d band" (orbitais localized prcdoiiuniinlly un the Pt Jtuin;>) II Ls 011 Jiilibumliiig combination (f^ff )ofthc PI-} d oibilals and the ad- p - - 2-0 - 4J) - y - &D ?- &0 Pt'ff .-- S - 1(U) -- 12JO . - 1 J) IRA Vil;. 3. Orbilal eacify diagram for the ground late confifuia- tion ofa CIJ3CP13 cluslci oblamcd with a SCF Xn calcula- lk>o. Unoccupied Icvcb aie iknolcd by an aslcrBk. jacent carbon p Orbitals that are parallel to the sur- face. The lowest unoccupied orbitais of a[ and e sym- metry arc also iintibonding Pt(d) C(p) combinations. The a) orbital (o^-p, ) is composed of a carbon p or- bital normal to ihc surface and metal d orbitais, while the e orbital ("^p, ) involves (he carbon p orbitais parallel to the surtace and metal d-orbitals. We can now assign the bound state transition peaks (A) in the clhylidync spcclia to stales that arc ihc surface analo RUCS of unoccupied oibitals in the 11301*13 cluster. The slate analogous to the unoccupied 3. orbital then Ls found in near-grazing spcclia at 285.7 cV and the slate analogous to the c orbital appeals at 285.4 eV in the noimal incidence data Such a small cneipy differ- ence is difficult to calculate reliably with the SCI-' Xa method and, as we can sec, the unoccupied c orbital is placed "^0.8 cV above the a| level in rig. 3. The me- thyl carbon participates to only a small extent in this bound state excitation since the oibilals being filled a e localised predominantly on (he lower car- bon atom. NI^XAI-'S spectra may aLso be used to obtain bond lengths of small chemisorbcd molecules 11.3). The quasi-bound stale transition can be viewed as a molec- ular excitation, or cquivalently, as a multiple.scattei- mg shape resonance where the pholoclcclron is scat- tered between the absorbing carbon and its nearest- neighhoiing atoms. We have recently shown |3] that for small species (such as CO, ('1130 and Ht'O^) chemi- sorbed on CU( 100) the resonance position above threshold. A, is related to the intra-rnolccular distance, R. by the simple equation (Vn + A)/ 2 - Cn where VQ is the ninci potential in the inlerstilial molecular region that determines the y.ero ofcneigy and wave vector of the photoelectron relative to the Fenni level and CQ is a constant which depends on the atomic scattciiup phase shifts, for both clhylcne and cthyli- dyne, the scattering process involves a pail of carbon atoms so the inner potential and the scattering phase shift arc the same. The larger A value observed for clhylidync (1 1.0 cV) compared to cthylenc (9.6 eV) implies a shorter ( 0.03 A) C-(: bond in ethylidyne. This LS surprising since the ethylidync C- C bond is nominally a single bond and is expected to be larger than the double bond in cthylene. As suggested previ- ously |9], the C C bond of elhylidyne may be shor- tened to ^1.45 A, while the C C bond of cthylenc may be lengthened to moic than ;t-" 1.45 A due to the 334 Volume 105, number 3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 16 March 1984 large n* character in the occupied (TT* + d) orbital. In summary, using the polarization dependence of the NEXAFS spectra, we find that ethylene lies down on the Pt(l 11) surface in a Tr-bonded configuration at 90 K- Upon heating to 300 K, the C-C bond rotates perpendicular to the surface as is expected for ethyli- dyne formation. From our SCF Xa calculation on a CH^CPt^ cluster, we assign the bound state transi- tions observed in the NEXAFS spectra at different X- ray incidence angles to Is- - a^-pt and n'*pt excita- tions. Surprisingly, the nominal single-bond C C bond distance ofethylidyne is measured to be shorter (by ==0 03 A) than that for chemisorbed ethylene. head.ce:title: Orientation and bonding of ethylene and ethylidyne on Pt(111) by means of near-edge x-ray absorption fine structure spectroscopy

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Department of Chemistry, University of California, Berkeley, California 94720, USA
Corporate Research Science Laboratories, Exxon Research and Engineering Company, Clinton Township, Annandale, New Jersey 08801, USA

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Near-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (NEXAFS) spectra have been measured for ethylene chemisorbed on Pt(111) at 90 and 300 K. From the polarization dependence of the spectra at 90 K, ethylene is found to lie down with a π bond to the surface. The spectra collected at 300 K indicate a CC bond normal to the surface in ethylidyne, and a SCF Xα calculation was carried out to assign the K-edge transitions in this species. The ethylidyne carboncarbon bond (which is nominally a single bond) appears to be shorter (≈0.03 A) than that for chemisorbed ethylene.

sb:title.sb:maintitle: Electron energy loss spectroscopy and surface vibrations
